# location(_:offsetBy:)

**Instance Method**

Returns a new text location object based on an existing location and offset you provide.

## Declaration

```swift
func location(_ location: any NSTextLocation, offsetBy offset: Int) -> (any NSTextLocation)?
```

## Parameters

- **location**: The starting location. For example, you might specify the beginning or end of the document as the starting location.
- **offset**: The number of characters from the starting location. Specify a positive integer to create a location object that comes after the starting location. Specify a negative number to create a location object that comes before the starting location.

## Return Value

An [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/NSTextLocation] object that corresponds to the new location, or `nil` if the new location exceeds the bounds of the text.

## Discussion

You can get [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/NSTextLocation] objects for the start and end of the text storage from the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/NSTextElementProvider/documentRange] property of the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/NSTextElementProvider] protocol, which [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/NSTextContentStorage] implements. If you provide an [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/NSTextLocation] object doesn’t match the type of the ones in the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/NSTextElementProvider/documentRange] property, this method throws an exception.

## Finding ranges, locations, and offsets

- **offset(from:to:)**: Returns the number of characters between the specified locations.
- **adjustedRange(from:forEditingTextSelection:)**: Returns the text range, if any, in the backing store that required manual adjustment after editing.
